message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient shows symptoms of liver disease, and histopathological examination shows PAS-positive globules, which suggest alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. The genetic analysis shows a substitution of lysine for glutamic acid, which is associated with the PiZZ genotype. The other options are not associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation suggests alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, which is an autosomal recessive disorder that is most commonly due to the PiZZ genotype. The genetic analysis confirms the presence of a protease inhibitor gene mutation, and PAS-positive globules within periportal hepatocytes suggest the accumulation of alpha-1 antitrypsin in the liver. The other options are not associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, elevated serum transaminases, and histopathological examination suggest that he has alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. The gene located on chromosome 14 that encodes for a protease inhibitor is responsible for this condition, and PiZZ is the most common genotype associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient most likely has alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, which is associated with PAS-positive globules within hepatocytes and can cause liver damage. The genotype that most commonly causes alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is PiZZ. None of the other options are associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has yellow discoloration of the skin, abdominal pain, and elevated transaminases, which suggest liver damage. The histopathological examination of a liver biopsy shows PAS-positive globules, which suggest alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. The genetic analysis indicates that the patient has a substitution of lysine for glutamic acid at position 342 of the alpha-1 antitrypsin gene, which is characteristic of the PiZZ genotype.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of cholestatic hepatitis, which suggests alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. The genetic analysis shows a substitution of lysine for glutamic acid at position 342, which corresponds to the PiZZ genotype. All other options involve different amino acid substitutions or combinations.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including yellow discoloration of the skin, fatigue, and elevated transaminases, suggest liver disease. The presence of PAS-positive globules in periportal hepatocytes and the genetic analysis suggest alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, which is most common in patients with PiZZ genotype. The other options have different combinations of Pi alleles.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, which is caused by a homozygous mutation in the SERPINA1 gene. The genotype for this disease is PiZZ.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description matches α1-antitrypsin deficiency, which is caused by mutations in the SERPINA1 gene on chromosome 14. The most common mutation causing α1-antitrypsin deficiency is the PiZZ genotype, where glutamic acid is replaced by lysine at position 342. Therefore, option (A) is the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of liver disease and has a genetic mutation in the gene that encodes for a protease inhibitor, indicating a diagnosis of alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. PiZZ is the most severe form of the disease, which presents with low levels of alpha-1 antitrypsin in the serum and predisposes individuals to liver and lung disease. PiSS, PiMS, and PiSZ are all milder forms of the disease.
